2.title: Review: Matrix Operations

20.body: Let's quickly recap how to represent a hyperplane in n-D space. In high school, we learned a line in 2D space can be represented as: y=ax+b This is equivalent to: w1​x+w2​y+b=0 For a plane in 3D: w1​x+w2​y+w3​z+b=0 For a hyperplane in n-D: w1​x1​+w2​x2​+w3​x3​+...+wn​xn​+b=0 Which is equivalent to: wTx+b=0 This is the general form of a line, plane, and hyperplane. Here, w∈Rn×1. If n=2, it's a line; if n=3, it's a plane; if n>3, it's a hyperplane. Alternatively: θTx=0,θ∈Rn+1×1 So, let's first try to investigate SVM in 2-D space. A line divides points into 2 classes. Thus, our decision function is: hw,b​=g(wTx+b) g(z)=1, if z≥0; g(z)=−1, if z<0
20.title: Intuition

21.body: To know the confidence level of our classification result, the first intuition might be: directly input the point's coordinates into the line and use the magnitude and sign of the result to tell the correctness and confidence of our classification. Suppose the point is (x1​,x2​), and the classification result is y1​. Here is the definition of funciton margin γ^​=y(wTx+b) However, this margin is not ideal. If we scale both w and b up, the hyperplane remains unchanged, but the function margin scales up. So, here comes the definition of geometric margin , which is the distance from the data point to the hyperplane. γ=∥w∥wT(x+b)​ Note: when ∥w∥=1, function margin = geometric margin.
21.title: Margin

22.body: We only care about the min margin when the hyperplane is fixed. We try to find the hyperplane which maximize the minimum margin. Expressing the above in mathematical terms: γ,w,bmax​s.t.​γy(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥γ,i=1,...,m​ The above equation indicates: we want to maximize the γ γ is the minimum margin acheivable for all traning exampls ∥w∥=1 is to let γ^​=γ γ,w,bmax​s.t.​∥w∥γ^​​y(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥γ,i=1,...,m​ This is form is still not convex, so we constraint that γ^​=1, by scaling up w and b. γ,w,bmax​s.t.​∥w∥1​y(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥1,i=1,...,m​ Equivalently: γ,w,bmin​s.t.​21​∥w∥2y(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥1,i=1,...,m​
22.title: The optimal margin classifier

23.body: Adding a penalize term for ourtliers γ,w,bmin​bs.t.​21​∥w∥2+Ci=1∑n​ξi​y(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥1−ξi​, i=1,...,mξi​≥1​ C: is the egularization parameter we can choose, how much we want to penalize the outliers. Bigger C means we places more emphasis on minimizing the classification error, potentially at the expense of a smaller margin. ξi​: is the slack variable. if ξi​=0, the data point is correctly classifed outside the margin. if ξi​>0, the data point is either misclassified or within the margin.
23.title: Outliers?

25.body: Consider the following problem xmin​s.t.​f(x)hi​(x)=0, i=1,...,l​ Thus, Lagrangian L is defined as: L(x1​,x2​,…,xn​,λ)=f(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)+λ⋅g(x1​,x2​,…,xn​) then set the partial derivatives of L with respect to each xi​ and λ to zero: ∂x1​∂L​∂x2​∂L​∂xn​∂L​∂λ∂L​​=0=0⋮=0=0​ λ can be interpreted as the rate of change of the maximum (or minimum) value of the original function as the constraint is varied.
25.breadcrumbs: svm » Quick recap of Lagrange multipliers
25.title: Quick recap of Lagrange multipliers

26.body: Given the primal problem for soft-margin SVM: γ,w,bmin​s.t.​21​∥w∥2+Ci=1∑n​ξi​y(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥1−ξi​, i=1,...,mξi​≥1​ We can form the Lagrangian: L(w,b,ξ,α,β)=21​∥w∥2+Ci=1∑n​ξi​−i=1∑n​αi​[yi​(w⋅xi​+b)−1+ξi​]−i=1∑n​βi​ξi​ Form the min and max condition again, w,ξmin​α≥0,β≥0max​L(w,b,ξ,α,β) Uder Slater condition, changing min and max order does not affect the optimal condition, α≥0,β≥0max​dew,ξmin​L(w,b,ξ,α,β) Setting the derivatives of the Lagrangian to zero: With respect to w: ∂w∂L​=w−i=1∑n​αi​yi​xi​=0 This gives: w=i=1∑n​αi​yi​xi​ With respect to b: ∂b∂L​=−i=1∑n​αi​yi​=0 With respect to ξi​: ∂ξi​∂L​=C−αi​−βi​=0
26.breadcrumbs: svm » Apply Lagrange multiplier to SVM dual problem
26.title: Apply Lagrange multiplier to SVM dual problem

3.body: Vector norm: general form: ∥x∥p​=(i=1∑n​∣xi​∣p)1/p l1​ norm: ∣∣x∣∣1​=i=1∑n​xi​ l2​ norm: Euclidean 可以理解为向量的长度或大小 ∣∣x∣∣2​=i=1∑n​xi2​​ l∞​ norm: max xi​ ∣∣x∣∣∞​∣∣=maxi​∣xi​∣ Matrix norm: i.e. Frobenius norm 也可以理解为矩阵的长度或者大小 ∣∣A∣∣F​=iˉ=1∑m​jˉ​=1∑n​Aij2​​=tr(ATA)​

5.body: A=LU For square matrix only L: lower triangular matrix U: Upper triangular matrix Gaussian elimination with row operation, but no row exchange, if exchange, do it before decomposition
5.title: LU Decomposiiton

7.body: A=QΛQ−1 For diagonalizable matrix only Q is the matrix of eigenvectors. Λ is the diagonal matrix whose diagonal entries are the eigenvalues.
7.title: Eigendecomposition

8.body:
# Python code to compute eigendecomposition using NumPy
import numpy as np # Define a square matrix
A = np.array([[4, 2], [1, 3]]) # Compute eigenvalues and eigenvectors
eigenvalues, eigenvectors = np.linalg.eig(A) # Diagonal matrix of eigenvalues
Lambda = np.diag(eigenvalues) # Reconstruct the matrix
A_reconstructed = eigenvectors @ Lambda @ np.linalg.inv(eigenvectors) print("Original Matrix:\n", A)
print("\nEigenvalues:\n", eigenvalues)
print("\nEigenvectors:\n", eigenvectors)
print("\nReconstructed Matrix:\n", A_reconstructed)
8.title: Python Code

9.body: A=UΣV∗ For any m×n matrix U is an m×m unitary matrix Σ is an m×n diagonal matrix V∗ is the complex conjugate transpose of an n×n unitary matrix
